'''Sherman Robertson''' (born October 27, 1948, [[Breaux Bridge, Louisiana|Breaux Bridge]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States]])<ref name="AMG"/> is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] and [[singing|singer]], who has been described as "one part [[zydeco]], one part [[swamp blues]], one part [[electric blues]] and one part classic [[rhythm and blues]]."<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
Robertson was born in [[Louisiana]] and raised in [[Houston]], [[Texas]].<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| page= 159
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}</ref> At the age of 13, he watched a performance on television by [[Hank Williams]]. Duly inspired and equipped with a cheap guitar purchased by his father, he started playing the songs previously performed by [[Freddie King]] and [[Floyd London]]. As he lived close to the [[Duke Records|Duke]]/[[Peacock Records|Peacock]] [[recording studio]], Robertson took the opportunity to acquaint himself with some of the musicians who recorded there. At the same time, in his late [[Adolescence|teens]], Robertson played in a band in various [[bar (establishment)|bars]] of his [[Fifth Ward, Houston]] neighborhood.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 1982, [[Clifton Chenier]] heard Robertson's band playing at the Crosstown Blues Festival. Robertson moved back to Louisiana, learned to play [[slide guitar]], and toured for several years in the 1980s with Chenier.<ref name="AMG"/> Robertson contributed to his ''Live At The'' (1982) and ''San Francisco Blues Festival'' (1985) albums.<ref name="russell"/> After Chenier's death, Robertson played with [[Rockin' Dopsie]], appearing on his ''Crowned Prince Of Zydeco'' album (1986), and [[Terrance Simien]] & the Mallet Playboys, before going solo.<ref name="russell"/> 

In addition, Robertson's guitar work appeared on [[Paul Simon]]'s ''[[Graceland (album)|Graceland]]'' [[album]],<ref name="russell"/> and he was on the bill at the 1994 [[Notodden Blues Festival]].

Robertson's ''I'm the Man'' (1994) was the first release on the Code Blue label. It was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Award]].<ref>[http://www.houstonbluessociety.org/links/localbands.php?Id=75] {{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref> Robertson's follow-up, ''Here & Now'' (1995), included his [[cover version|cover]] of the [[Tracy Nelson (singer)|Tracy Nelson]] song "Here & Now".<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Richard Skelly |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sherman-robertson-mn0000027394/biography |title=Sherman Robertson | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1948-10-27 |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref> However the [[record label]] folded and Robertson re-appeared in 1998 on the independent label, Audioquest, with his next offering, ''Going Back Home''. In November 2005 he released ''Guitar Man - Live'' with his new backing band, BluesMove.

In 2008, Robertson and BluesMove played at the [[Harvest Time Blues]] [[music festival|festival]] in [[Monaghan]], [[Ireland]]. In 2011, Roberston and BluesMove appeared at the [[Rhythm Festival]] in [[Bedfordshire]], [[England]].<ref>[http://www.rhythmfestival.com/sherman-robertson] {{dead link|date=January 2014}}</ref>

In 2012, a proposed concert in [[Gaildorf]], [[Germany]], was cancelled after Robertson suffered a [[stroke]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://bmansblueslibrary.blogspot.co.uk/2012/10/guitar-man-sherman-robertson.html |title=Bman's Blues Library: Guitar Man - Sherman Robertson |publisher=Bmansblueslibrary.blogspot.co.uk |date=2012-10-27 |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref>

==Discography==
*''I'm the Man'' (1994) - [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]/Code Blue Records
*''Here & Now'' (1996) - Atlantic/Code Blue Records
*''Going Back Home'' (1998) - [[Sledgehammer Blues]] (formerly AudioQuest Music)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.valley-entertainment.com/going-back-home-1.html |title=Going Back Home |publisher=Valley-entertainment.com|accessdate=17 June 2010}}</ref>
*''Guitar Man - Live'' (2005) - Movin Records<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sherman-robertson-mn0000027394/discography |title=Sherman Robertson | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1948-10-27 |accessdate=2014-01-28}}</ref>
